title: IQR and Standard Deviation
question_text:
A set of normally distributed data has a mean $\mu = 80$ with an interquartile range (IQR) of $12$.
What is the approximate value of the standard deviation?
solution:

An IQR of $12$ means that $50\%$ of the values in this normal curve will be at $µ ± 6$, which are $74$ and $86$. The curve above shows the middle $50\%$ (IQR) shaded in, with $25\%$ of the data on the left tail, and $25\%$ of the data on the left tail.

The z-value corresponding to $74$ is $-0.675$, which is found by looking in the SNC table for the $z$-value associated with a left-tail probability of $0.25$ (or by using the Inv Norm command on a calculator).

Now use the conversion formula:

$$z =\dfrac{ X-\mu}{\sigma}$$

Substitute as follows:

$$-0.675 =\dfrac{ (74-80)}{\sigma }$$

$$(-0.675)(\sigma) = -6$$

Then solve for $\sigma$:

$$\dfrac{(-6)}{(-0.675)} ≈ 8.9$$

Choice 'C', or $9$, is the closest choice.
